prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: molecular-line mapping
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 20-point Mosaic mapping of the OMC-2,3 region. The frequency setup is cover N2H+ (1-0) (93.1734 GHz) HNC (1-0) (90.66356 GHz), and CH3CN (91.9871 GHz)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our previous VLA observations (Li et al. 2013, beam=5") revealed NH3 gas clumps with typical extent of 10 arcsec, line intensity of ~5 K and line width usually less than 2 km/s. A velocity resolution of 0.1 km/s is requested. The dense cores with the clumps are expected to have size of 1-5 arcsec. In the ALMA observation, in order to improve resolution and maintain a reasonable integration time (~10 hours) at the same time, a beam=2.5" seems to be an optimized choice.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Dust Continuum Mapping
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mosaic mapping of OMC-2,3 with the 2 mm dust continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In our previous CARMA observation towards to other two similar quiescent Orion cores, with beam=1.5", the maximum 3 mm continuum intensity is ~100 mJy/beam. Observed with the ALMA beam size (0.6", which is adopted based on the expected dense-core sizes 1"-5"), we expect a continuum flux of 20 mJy/beam. in order to guarantee the detection of relatively thinner gas components, an RMS=0.2 mJy/beam is requiested, which corresponds to an H2 column density of 0.4*10^22 cm^-2 and assming T_dust=20 K as calculated from the standard dust emission model (Ossenkopf & Henning 1994). This RMS level can be achieved within 24 seconds for each mapping point, and a total time of ~1 hour for all the points.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to map the massive quiescent filament in Orion in the dust band 4 continuum and the dense molecular tracers N2H+, CH3CN, HC3N, and HNC in band 3. With the unparalleled ALMA sensitivity and UV coverage we will sample scales from the pc-scale filament to 10^3 AU dense gas cores, resolving the thermal Jeans length. This will be the most complete gas and dust study with unprecedented fidelity from 2 arcsec to 20 arcmin. Thus, we will obtain precise measurements of the distribution of temperature, density, kinematics, and mass in OMC2/OMC3; characterizing the dynamical and chemical environment in Orion. These fundamental measurements will help us understand the interplay relation dense cores and the fragmentation of filaments, producing the most accurate CMF in the process, and likely finding for the first time the "first hydro-static cores" in a massive star formation region.
